CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper August 16, 1947, pg. 15, reads: "Steel PAC - Eight hundred and fifty thousand steelworkers, including 150,000 Negro members of the USW will hear constant exhortations to vote from this group of men, from now until the 1948 presidential elections. They were picked by Phillip Murray, president of the CIO and USW. Mr. Murray also chose Jack Thornton of Washington to corral the Negro vote. Left to right, seated: David J. McDonald, secretary-treasurer of PAC and USW; Jack Thornton, assistant director; Mayor John Mullin of Clairton, director, and George Pettigrew, controller. Standing: Lieuts. G. J. Conway, B. F. Gage, Frank Hoffman, Frank Annunzio, Phil Schieding, Michael A. Petrak, George Bennington, Earl Bester and Hugh Carcella. - Harris Photo."
TitMainTitle: Members of steel PAC, seated from left: David J. McDonald, Jack Thornton, Clairton Mayor John Mullin, George Pettigrew; standing: G. J. Conway, B. F. Gage, Frank Hoffman, Frank Annunzio, Phil Schieding, Michael A. Petrak, George Bennington, Earl Bester and Hugh Carcella gathered behind desk and observing "Taft Hartley Act" document, in office with fan and "The Thinker" bookends
